name: Breast Reconstruction Awareness Close the Loop 5K 2025
description:
Get ready to start your day with the eighth annual Close the Loop 5K!

Join us in the Crescent City of New Orleans, LA, on Friday, Oct. 10 at 7 a.m. CST, as we embark on a morning run/walk during PSTM25. Lace-up your sneakers and join plastic surgeons, patients, office staff, and supporters from across the globe as we come together to raise awareness and funds for breast reconstruction, charitable care and groundbreaking research.

Registration for the Close the Loop 5K will open on May 14, 2025.

As the sun rises, the excitement begins! Starting at 7 a.m., the #BRA5K will take place along the waterfront. Whether you're running, walking, or cheering from the sidelines, your participation fuels the Breast Reconstruction Awareness (BRA) Campaign of The Plastic Surgery Foundation (PSF), empowering us to make a tangible difference in the lives of those in need.

Breast cancer is a devastating disease, affecting approximately 1 in 8 women in the United States. Breast reconstruction is a very personal choice — every woman should have access to her options before she has to make a decision. Profits generated are awarded to organizations focused on awareness and assistance efforts of women fighting breast cancer or pursuing breast reconstructive surgery. Thanks to YOU, The Plastic Surgery Foundation's BRA Program has allocated 188 grants, totaling over $2 million in awards.

Mark your calendars, gather your gear, and join us for an unforgettable morning. See you at this year’s race!

Run, Walk, Cheer or Donate!

Whether you're running, walking, cheering from the sidelines (or the couch!), or donating, your support is invaluable! Join us for our 5K for Breast Reconstruction Awareness and help us empower individuals impacted by breast cancer to reclaim their bodies and their lives after breast cancer. Register as an individual, join a team (no limit on team size!), or become a team captain.

Not a runner? No problem!  Every donation, big or small, makes a difference.

Support our cause today and help us spread awareness, one step (or dollar!) at a time!

Help Us Close The Loop: Refer Friends & Earn a Refund!

Want to make an even bigger impact at the Close The Loop 5k for Breast Reconstruction Awareness? It's simple: invite your friends, family, and colleagues to join you!

This year, we're excited to offer referral rewards! Share your unique referral code, and when five people register using your code, you'll receive a $40 refund on your registration fee! That's right, running for a cause can actually save you money!

Help us spread awareness, build an even stronger community, and reach our fundraising goals. The more, the merrier (and the more funds raised for Breast Reconstruction Awareness)!

Share your referral code today and let's Close The Loop together!

300. Race proceeds benefit the JJK Foundation and her Winning In Life program,

community supporting many youth programs.

Hosted by The Boulder Watershed Collective and in collaboration with T.E.A.M Boulder, all money raised from the event will be donated to the town of Gold Hill, and will fund wildfire preparation and response initiatives such as forest restoration, home hardening, emergency planning, land stewardship, and community resiliency.

This event provides an opportunity for the Front Range trail community, to show its support for small mountain town communities that live with a high risk of disruption and destruction from wildfire, while providing visitors with access to their unique character, beauty, and the surrounding landscapes.

RACE DETAILS
Runners can choose between a 28K (17.4M), 12K (7.7M), 5K, or Kids 1K trail race. All distances start and finish on the main street of Gold Hill at the Gold Hill Inn, and the longer distances are run, in part, on the National Forest System roads. Runners will enjoy varied terrain of dirt roads and trails through ponderosa pine and aspen forests while taking in amazing views on these challenging courses.

The 28K course heads south to Salina, and then west along Fourmile Canyon Dr to the historic town of Sunset. From there, runners will head north up the Switzerland Trail and back to Gold Hill. The 12K course heads west along Gold Hill Rd to the famous Mount Alto Picnic area and back into town.

name: Gavin and Bryson Blount Memorial 5K
description:
In October 2021, 5 year old Gavin Blount was diagnosed with brain cancer. Only 3 months later, in January 2022, his 3 year old little brother Bryson was diagnosed with ALL Leukemia. Both Gavin and Bryson were diagnosed with CMMRD, or Constitutional Mismatch Repair Deficiency, which made both boys predisposed to developing aggressive cancers. Treatment began immediately for both boys.

Unfortunately, due to the boys having CMMRD, the cancers in each of the boys grew too rapidly despite their aggressive treatments. Sadly, on February 18, 2023, Gavin passed away at the age of 6. Only 10 months later, on December 19, 2023, Bryson passed away at the age of 5.

The Ahmad Butler Foundation (ABF) assisted the Blounts with everyday financial expenses, as well as funeral costs for both boys.  They continue to support the Blounts with a community of wonderful people who can understand and relate to all the family has been through.

The Ahmad Butler Foundation was established as a charitable nonprofit organization with a mission to support children with cancer and other life threatening diseases, while aiding in the improvement of their quality of life.  The ABF offers programs that focus on filling the educational, social, emotional, and financial gaps experienced by families post-diagnosis.  To date, ABF has served over 10,000 People.  ABF is also the leading group in the Million Family March, a march to demand congress allocate more money to childhood cancer research and support.

All proceeds from the race will go to The Ahmad Butler Foundation, to assist them in making a larger impact on families like the Blounts.

name: Spring Run The Farm
description:
Spring Run the Farm is a 5 mile trail race to be held at Muscoot Farm in Katonah/Somers, NY on May 17, 2026. 

Race start times:
-8:30AM Kids race #1 (Age 7-12)
-8:45AM Kids race #2 (Age 6 & under) Note: Kids Race #1 will be finished before Kids Race #2 gets underway.
-9:30AM Run The Farm

There are No Dogs ever allowed at Muscoot Farm. The farm is has many resident animals that are spooked by dogs of all sizes. This means dogs cannot run in the race.

Service dogs who are trained to perform a task are permitted by the ADA. 

Comfort dogs or emotional support dogs are not covered by the ADA and are not permitted at Muscoot Farm. 

Run The Farm and Kids Run The Farm is put on by Run the Farm Races and is sanctioned by USA Track and Field. 

See you at the Farm!

  • Single Teamers: Immediate Family Member(s) - your dependents (up to age 24) and 1 Guest

name: Anthony Gamma Memorial Run Benefit for Scouting
description:
Everyone is welcome to the Anthony Gamma Memorial Run to Benefit Scouting! This event honors a beloved Scout who recently passed away.  Run the 5K, walk the Memory Mile, or have your kiddos participate in the 100 Meter Dash! Proceeds benefit the financial assistance program for local Scouts in need. 

Each registered participant gets a t-shirt and bags filled with a variety of fun swag items. Food donated by Nothing Bundt Cakes of St. Peters, J & B Wellness Company and Sweet Spot Cake Shoppe. Packet Pick Up

Will be held on Friday September 26th at Big River Running Company 13969 Manchester Rd. Ballwin MO 63011 2:00pm-6:00pm and 7:00am at park on Race Day.

ABOUT ANTHONY GAMMA:

Anthony loved God, his country, his family, his friends, and the outdoors!  Scouting provided abundant opportunities for him to go fishing, hiking, and camping with his friends and family.  He enjoyed learning skills scouting gave him to amplify these opportunities.  As a Cub Scout, Anthony really loved Cub World and the climbing tower.  Fall hayrides, campfires at night, and making s’mores were Anthony’s favorites!  Pinewood Derby was anticipated with enthusiasm and joy every year!  As a Boy Scout, he really enjoyed the lake activities at S-F, woodcarving, hiking, and bonfires.  Camping out in the tent was a big favorite and Anthony loved to retell camping stories.  He loved Beaumont and S-F scout camps as well as numerous other camping excursions.  He enjoyed so many scout activities especially learning the skills and interacting with others to earn merit badges.
He achieved the rank of Life Scout.  Anthony’s love for God, his country, his family, his friends, and all of nature was fed and magnified through scouting.  His enthusiasm for the outdoors and the friendships he made with fellow scouts as well as his scouting leaders and counselors were very important to him.  He was an avid athlete and especially loved baseball, golf, football, and basketball.  He was always a team player and gave his all in every sport he played.  Anthony loved and appreciated his family, friends, fellow scouts, teammates, leaders, and coaches.  He would want the same for others!

name: Ben Campbell Memorial 5K
description:
Benjamin Cole Campbell was a go-getter, destined for greatness, and though he’s no longer with us, we pledge to keep his legacy alive forever.  The Benjamin Campbell Memorial Fund has been established to keep Ben's legacy alive by helping other students achieve. Ben's journey is a reminder that given the opportunity, with hard work and focus, you can achieve.

 

Ben’s childhood was anything but easy. His mother, Carla, was diagnosed with Leukemia and fought hard for many years. As years passed her health rapidly declined. Ben and his siblings were enrolled at Milton Hershey School, in hopes that Carla would win the fight against Leukemia and their family would be reunited. The disease eventually took its toll on her and she lost her battle, a week prior to Ben’s 8th grade graduation. The family struggled with the devastating loss - now four children without a mom. 

 

While at Milton Hershey, Ben played football and was an asset to the team. Football was his anchor - he found a way to release his anger and frustration, kept his grades, and stayed focused; however, home is where his heart needed to be. He wanted to be back home with his dad. His dad agreed to let him come home, and he enrolled in Newark High School. Not long after his arrival, he had made new friends and was voted junior captain of the football team. It was here he met his future fiancé, Shannon.

 

Ben was determined to continue his education after high school and played football at Wesley College. He worked really hard and graduated with honors. He was able to see his Dad and siblings and thought all the hard work would pay off. He worked hard every day...really hard. Quotes in this letter are from his application to Widener Law School. Telling his story he said, "Nothing in my life has been handed to me. I worked hard for every accolade. I expect to work hard to earn my law degree and when the academics get tough, I will never give up. When I earn my degree, I will use it to help as many families as possible.”

 

Ben graduated from Widener Law School in May of 2021 with honors! He worked part time for Baird Mandalas Brockstedt and Federico LLC while he studied for the bar exam. Again, he rallied with friends and studied like it was a full-time job. His work ethic was an amazing example of grit and determination. He passed the Bar and was hired by Baird, Mandalas, Brockstedt, and Federico LLC full time. He did it... he overcame his circumstances!

 

Ben was engaged to his high school sweetheart, Shannon, and was to be married on October 7, 2023. They attended Newark High School and Wesley together. They were champions with a pursuit of helping others, She became an RN at Christiana Hospital. His fairytale was coming true.

 

On July 29 tragedy struck. Eight weeks before he was to marry the love of his life, Ben was killed in an accident and taken from us. No farewell words were spoken. No time to say goodbye. He was gone before we knew it and now we are left asking why.

 

Since last July, the Campbell Family and Ben’s friends and extended family have been picking up the pieces of this horrible tragedy. The Ben Campbell Memorial Fund has been established to help others, as Ben would have wanted and what he devoted his career to doing. We would love to see as many people out to celebrate Ben’s life and raise as much money as possible for the Fund. The 5k will start and end at Ben’s Alma Mater, Newark High School. The course will take you through the City of Newark. We welcome all walkers and runners of all abilities. 

 

There will be a post-rate after party at Deer Park Tavern starting at 10:30am. There will be amazing raffles to purchase tickets for and other donation and fundraising opportunities. We would love to see everyone after. 

 

“Teams” are made for Newark High School Alumni, MIlton Hershey School Alumni, Wesley Alumni, Delaware Law Alumni, ChristianaCare, Baird, Mandalas, and Brockstedt & Federico LLC that you can join when you register for the race. All of these organizations were major pillars in Ben’s life, and we would love to see as many people from each of these groups as possible! If you would like to make an additional team, please feel free to do so at sign up. 

 

Click HERE for more information on The Ben Campbell Memorial Fund

A wish can change everything for these children - giving them the strength and hope they need to persevere in their fight against critical illness. The summertime is Make-A-Wish® Connecticut's busiest wish-granting season, but it can also be a time when we receive the least amount of financial support. name: Folds of Honor Bethel Veteran's Day 5K
description:
It began with Lt Col Dan Rooney’s flight home from his second tour of duty in Iraq. An F-16 fighter pilot in the Oklahoma Air National Guard, he became painfully aware of the realities families face when a loved one in uniform is fallen or disabled.

As his flight landed, the pilot announced they carried the remains of Corporal Brock Bucklin on board. Lt Col Rooney watched as Corporal Bucklin’s twin brother walked somberly alongside the flag-covered casket to meet his family on the tarmac. Among them was the deceased Corporal’s young son, Jacob.

Since that night, Lt Col Rooney has committed his life to rallying patriotic Americans and meeting sacrifice with hope through the Folds of Honor. Since 2007, Folds of Honor has provided life-changing scholarships to the spouses and children of fallen or disabled military and first responders. On our watch, those who protect our freedoms and our families will know they are not forgotten.

name: Run for Their Lives 5k
description:
Choices Crisis Pregnancy Center is devoted to providing free and confidential services to women and men facing decisions about a potential pregnancy related issue.

  • Our private and non-judgmental approach is based on truth, current options. 
  • Our promise is to offer information and services for as long as the client is in need.

Our Mission

Choices Crisis Pregnancy Center is a nonprofit, confidential and non-judgmental center that provides life changing and life saving services to women and men regardless of age, race, financial ability or religion. Our purpose is to defend and enable the right to life for the pre-born. Our goal is to counsel and educate our community about the choices and truth of parenting, adoptions, sexual integrity and the negative effects of abortion. We are committed to offer resources as well as free indefinite counseling with love and gentleness. Our belief is based on Christian integrity and is upheld through obedience to and faith in Jesus Christ our Lord.

Our Goals

Choices Crisis Pregnancy Center is and will continue to be non-profit to all clients. Our purpose and goal is to provide pregnancy resources and counseling which line up with Christian values. In addition, we have met our goal to develop an in-house medical expansion which provides free pregnancy testing, ultrasounds, abortion pill reversal, STI testing, prenatal care and sexual integrity programming. Choices will continue to stand for the right to life for the unborn and will do so using forgiveness, compassion, education, and love as exemplified by Jesus Christ our Lord.

name: Down Syndrome Festival & 5k
description:
The DSACO Festival & 5K will be held on Saturday, September 27, 2025, at the Myriad Botanical Gardens in Oklahoma City, OK. 
Join us and help celebrate the extra 21st chromosome by creating a team, walking or running for acceptance and inclusion.

The event is free and open to the public. The 5k and 1-Mile Fun Run begins at 8 a.m at the Myriad Botanical Gardens, start line is on Sheridan Avenue. The Awareness Walk will line up at the start line on Sheridan Avenue at 9:45 a.m. Immediately following the awareness walk, join us on the Great Lawn at the Myriad Botanical Gardens for festival activities, which include raffles, inflatables, face painters, carnival games, music, talent shows, cotton candy, food trucks, and much more. There will also be resource vendors available to answer any questions or provide additional information. Complimentary parking is available in the lots directly south of the Myriad Botanical Gardens, accessed on Reno Avenue. We encourage everyone to arrive early to get a good parking spot!

Event Schedule
7:00-8:00 am: Registration/Check-in, Sheridan Lawn, Myriad Botanical Gardens
8:00 am: 1-Mile Fun Run and 5K, Start Line on Sheridan Avenue
9:45 am: Awareness Walk at the Start Line on Sheridan Avenue
10:00 am: Festival Begins, Great Lawn, Myriad Botanical Gardens
11:30 am: Raffle Drawings at Band Shell

Start Your Team Today!
Family members, friends, and co-workers are forming teams to walk, raise money and celebrate people with Down syndrome. Select a team name and start raising money by conducting a social media or e-mail campaign, asking for donations online, and recruiting as many awareness walkers and runners as possible. Many teams bring team posters or wear team t-shirts for the walk. Register to run or register under the Team Captain section. Once registered, you can start collecting donations online, by cash, check, or credit card. Please contact DSACO at 405-600-9981 or info@dsaco.org with any questions.

Who do the proceeds benefit?
Each year, this event gives the association and our families the chance to raise awareness about Down syndrome and is the largest fundraising event for DSACO. All money raised will stay in the central Oklahoma area to fund the many programs, activities, and services. Our mission is "to raise awareness and provide resources, as well as promote acceptance and inclusion for people with Down syndrome."

We accomplish these goals through a number of programs including:

  • Enrichment Lab and free tutoring services for individuals with Down syndrome
  • Microwave-based cooking classes for teens and adult
  • New parent packets and quarterly new parent breakfasts
  • Parent-to-parent support meetings
  • Workshops for parents, self-advocates, and educators
  • Scholarships for families to attend national conventions
  • Education and medical outreach initiatives
  • Family and teen/adult events and programs
  • As always, we will continue to further our mission of promoting acceptance and inclusion!

For additional information, please visit the FAQ page or email info@dsaco.org  

THANK YOU for supporting DSACO's mission to 
"raise awareness and provide resources, as well as promote acceptance and inclusion for people with Down syndrome."

name: Swazi 5K
description:
The Swazi 5K is a popular event in its 17th year. People from all ages over central Oklahoma come to participate in a walk/run to raise funds for needed ministries in Eswatini, Africa (formally Swaziland) and in Bethany. Bethany First Church of the Nazarene is an active local church serving its community as well as the world in an effort to bring hope and healing to the nations through Christ.

 

Eswatini Partnership

The Eswatini Partnership is a cooperative effort between the Eswatini Church of the Nazarene, Eswatini Nazarene Health Institutions, NCM Africa, Bethany First Church of the Nazarene, and Southern Nazarene University. Our goal is to come alongside Eswatini in their efforts to combat HIV/AIDS, TB, noncommunicable diseases, and the domestic abuse of women and children.

name: BWell Saginaw Strides Toward Wellness 2025
description:
STRIDES TOWARD WELLNESS 10K, 5K & 3K “Turtles & Hares” 2025
The BWell Saginaw Partner Coalition along with Dig Deep Race Events invite you to the third annual Race to BWell (10K Run, 5K Run/Walk & 3K “Turtles & Hares” Untimed Run/Walk)!

5K, 10K and Challenge For Change
All registered 10K and 5K Race/Walk participants will receive a professionally timed, USATF-sanctioned event, BWell finisher medal, and race shirt (if selected). Top three male and female finishers will receive prizes. Runners passing through the finish arch will be photographed, with photos available online and free of charge to participants for download or sharing. 5K & 10K participants will also receive everything listed in the 3K “Turtles & Hares” event description below!

  • Family-friendly course - a portion of which passes through the Saginaw Children’s Zoo

The 3K event is open to the community and all ages.  Strollers/wheelchairs, and other accommodations are welcome to participate in this 3k run or walk. This is a USA Track & Field Sanctioned event. A portion of proceeds will benefit ongoing BWell Saginaw activities.

name: The 2026 Hoag OC Marathon Running Festival (Expo Registration)
description: The Hoag OC Marathon Running Festival includes four different runs during the first weekend in May annually. The weekend of running begins at the OC Fair and Event Center on Saturday morning with the award winning Hoag Kids Run the OC when nearly 9,000 kids from over 150 Orange County schools participate. The afternoon kicks off with the CELEBRATE OC Festival with local sports teams, craft brews and some of Orange County's iconic brands and live music all day. Later in the day on Saturday, the OC 5K takes place with a fun, flat tour of the OC Fairgrounds and nearby Orange Coast College followed by the Celebrate OC Finish Festival. Sunday morning begins early in Newport Beach. The exceptional OC Marathon & Half Marathon course is a blend of chic coastal scenery, tranquil nature and sophisticated arts and shopping which equal the best of OC. Enjoy breathtaking views of the Pacific Ocean and cruise down historic PCH through the seaside village of Corona del Mar. Run above pristine wetlands of Upper Newport, the Arts District and shopping mecca of South Coast Plaza in the "Heart of the OC" to the supportive cheers of residents in the many diverse neighborhoods and finish with a huge party at the Sunday Celebrate Finish Festival at the OC Fair and Event Center.

name: Tara Sturgis Memorial Pints & Paws 5K & 1 mile 2025
description:
Bring your four-legged friend out for some exercise and support a great cause!  Tara Sturgis Memorial Pints & Paws 5K and 1 mile fun run/walk takes place at Carl's Family YMCA in Milford, Michigan on Sunday morning, September 21, 2025.

All race participants will receive a race shirt and finisher medal. All four-legged friends will receive a custom race bandana.

All participants will receive a ticket for a discount off your entire bill at River's Edge Brewery.

The Pints and Paws run/walk is a family friendly & pet friendly event that honors Tara (Tabbert) Sturgis’s memory with 100% of the proceeds to provide grants to animal welfare groups. The Tara Sturgis Memorial Fund supports programs and organizations that provide general welfare services, emergency and medical services, or foster and adoption services for animals.

  • Guarantee your race shirt by pre-registering before September 8, 2025.

name: NCMC Turkey Trot
description:

name: Maddie's Message Race to Secure 5K
description:
Come join the Maddie's Message 5k - Race to Secure!   This is a family friendly event, hosted on the famous Virginia Beach boardwalk. Enjoy the smell of the ocean air as you race for a great cause!  Participating in the Maddie’s Message Race is more than just a run—it’s a powerful step toward saving lives. This 5K event supports a mission that hits close to home: raising awareness about furniture tip-over hazards and promoting child safety in every household. Here’s why your involvement matters:

  • Honor Maddie’s Legacy with Action: Maddie’s Message was founded in memory of a vibrant young girl whose life was tragically cut short due to an unsecured piece of furniture. This race carries her legacy forward by working to prevent similar tragedies through education and advocacy.
  • Support Critical Safety Initiatives: The race aims to raise $50,000 to fund life-saving efforts—public awareness campaigns, furniture anchor giveaways, and educational materials for parents, caregivers, and communities. Your steps directly support safer homes for children everywhere.
  • Help Prevent Tragedies Before They Happen: Every 30 minutes, a child is injured by a furniture tip-over incident. Many of these accidents are preventable with simple safety measures. By running this race, you help shine a light on an overlooked but urgent issue.
  • Be a Voice for Change: The Maddie’s Message Race builds momentum for stronger safety standards and pushes for industry accountability. Your participation helps raise the volume of this critical conversation and ensures that furniture safety is treated as a top priority.
  • Join a Movement That Saves Lives: Whether you’re a parent, grandparent, caregiver, or advocate, this race is your chance to be part of a community dedicated to protecting children. It’s more than a 5K—it’s a movement for safer homes and stronger families.

By running the Maddie’s Message 5K, you’re not just supporting a good cause—you’re taking meaningful steps toward a safer future for all children. Help us reach our $50,000 goal and anchor change where it starts: at home. Run for Maddie. Run for safety. Run to make a difference.

Maddie Message is an active advocate for furniture safety.  Our goal is to reduce the more than 50,000 injuries that occur each year due to furniture tip over through education and distribution of furniture straps.

FAQ’s

Can I run/walk with a stroller?

Unfortunately, no. A large portion of the run/walk course is “out and back” along the narrow river trail and strollers of any sort would impede runners and walkers in both directions.

What does “USATF Sanctioning” mean?

It means that organizers have followed a process with USA Track & Field that requires creation of a safety plan and purchase of outstanding insurance covering participants, volunteers, sponsors, partners and organizers of the event.  It also means that your race results will be official for scoring purposes (assuming you track that sort of thing).

Refund and Transfer Policy

We completely understand that plans change and athletes will sometimes be unable to compete in an event they've signed up for.  We also understand that registering for one of our events is a financial investment in that race. We accept your registration funds with the full intention of putting on the promised event with the listed amenities and we use your registration funds to pay for the necessary items and services needed to host the event. With that in mind, refunds will not be provided for this event unless the event is cancelled for reasons within our control.  The following are examples (but not limited to) of reasons an event might be canceled that are NOT within our control: Dangerous weather; natural disasters; pandemics; acts of terrorism; local emergencies; government mandates; and any situation creating a threat to safety of participants, volunteers, staff or bystanders.

Should an athlete have an injury or other medical issue keeping them from competing in an event they've registered for, we would be happy to transfer their registration to a similar Dig Deep-owned event up to and including the same event the following season.  A doctor's slip may be required as proof of injury or ailment.  Failure to provide proof if requested will result in non-transfer of the event.

Transferring registrations to other runners/athletes is NOT allowed.
